articles.headline: Spill Is Election Issue Far Beyond Gulf
articles.snippet: Candidates from both parties and from around the country are trying to turn the oil spill to their advantage.
articles.abstract: Candidates from both parties and from around the country are trying to turn the oil spill to their advantage.

articles.headline: The Roberts Court Comes of Age
articles.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. took control of his court this year, pushing hard on issues of concern to him, including campaign finance and gun rights.
articles.abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. took control of his court this year, pushing hard on issues of concern to him, including campaign finance and gun rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Last June, the Supreme Court term ended with restraint and a cliffhanger, as the court left the Voting Rights Act intact and ordered re-argument in Citizens United, the big campaign finance case.

articles.headline: Bank Fee Is Eliminated in Financial Bill
articles.snippet: Congressional negotiators voted down a tax on big banks, instead adopting a new plan to pay the legislation’s cost.
articles.abstract: Congressional negotiators voted down a tax on big banks, instead adopting a new plan to pay the legislation’s cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congressional negotiators briefly reopened the conference proceedings on a sweeping financial regulatory bill on Tuesday after Senate Republicans who had supported an earlier version of the measure threatened to block final approval unless Democrats removed a proposed tax on big banks and hedge funds.

articles.headline: Google to Stop Redirecting China Users
articles.snippet: The move is an effort to appease Beijing as Google seeks to renew its license to operate in mainland China.
articles.abstract: The move is an effort to appease Beijing as Google seeks to renew its license to operate in mainland China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google plans to stop automatically sending users in mainland China to its uncensored Hong Kong site, in an effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its license to operate in China.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and David Barboza

articles.headline: Governments Move to Cut Spending, in 1930s Echo
articles.snippet: The world’s rich countries are betting that the private sector can make up for withdrawn stimulus spending.
articles.abstract: The world’s rich countries are betting that the private sector can make up for withdrawn stimulus spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s rich countries are now conducting a dangerous experiment. They are repeating an economic policy out of the 1930s — starting to cut spending and raise taxes before a recovery is assured — and hoping today’s situation is different enough to assure a different outcome.

articles.headline: Larry King to End Show in the Fall
articles.snippet: In the face of falling ratings, Larry King said he would stay at CNN in a limited capacity, hosting several special shows.
articles.abstract: In the face of falling ratings, Larry King said he would stay at CNN in a limited capacity, hosting several special shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the face of falling ratings, the CNN host Larry King announced Tuesday evening that he would end his long-running talk show, “Larry King Live,” this fall.

articles.headline: Circuit Breaker Kicks In, Stopping Trades of Citigroup
articles.snippet: Trading was paused for five minutes after a large trade was posted at a price 12.7 percent lower than the previous trade.
articles.abstract: Trading was paused for five minutes after a large trade was posted at a price 12.7 percent lower than the previous trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: An experimental circuit breaker for stock markets that was put in place after last month’s so-called flash crash kicked in for the second time on Tuesday after an erroneous trade caused a sudden plunge in the price of Citigroup shares.

articles.headline: Stores See Google as Ally in E-Book Market
articles.snippet: Google may soon become the primary source of e-books on the Web sites of hundreds of independent booksellers.
articles.abstract: Google may soon become the primary source of e-books on the Web sites of hundreds of independent booksellers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Independent bookstores were battered first by discount chains like Barnes & Noble, then by superefficient Web retailers like Amazon.com.

articles.headline: In U.S. Bailout of A.I.G., Forgiveness for Big Banks
articles.snippet: Federal regulators ignored recommendations to force banks that did business with A.I.G. to accept losses.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators ignored recommendations to force banks that did business with A.I.G. to accept losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of the American International Group’s annual meeting last month, a shareholder approached the microphone with a question for Robert Benmosche, the insurer’s chief executive.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson
